context: The optimum δ cut-off point was evaluated by means of the sensitivity analysis (using contingency tables) and likelihood ratios. The global yield of the pre-treatment 13C-urea breath test to predict H. pylori eradication was calculated using the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve. A multiple logistic regression analysis was performed, to study in more detail the influence of δ 13C-urea breath test value, together with other variables, on H. pylori eradication success. The dependent variable was H. pylori eradication success/failure and independent variables were, in addition to δ 13C-urea breath test value, age, sex, smoking (smokers or non-smokers), type of disease (peptic ulcer or functional dyspepsia) and type of eradication therapy (first-line treatment or rescue regimen after failure of H. pylori eradication with previous therapy). Two different logistic regression models were used: one including δ 13CO2 as its numerical value (as a continuous variable), and another where δ 13CO2 was categorised as low (<35 δ units) and high (≥35 δ units), based on previously published studies. We used a backward modelling strategy and the log-likelihood ratio was statistic for model comparison. In total, 600 patients were included in this study: 312 (52%) received first-line eradication regimen (1-week proton pump inhibitor-based triple therapy), and 288 (48%) received rescue regimens (after failure of H. pylori eradication with previous therapy).
